content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are somewhat careful and tend to avoid taking risks unless absolutely necessary. You weigh the pros and cons thoroughly before making decisions. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this as a repeated game with an unknown strategy of my opponent. In a one-time scenario, it might seem beneficial to pick R since it has a higher payoff when the opponent picks B (42$ vs 0$). However, in a repeated game, it's essential to ensure that I can sustain a decent average payoff over the 75 rounds.

In this case, if my opponent is rational and also wants a decent average payoff, they would likely not stick to picking B every time since it results in a lower average payoff (12$ per round) compared to R (42$ or 45$, depending on their choice). However, if they pick R occasionally to take advantage of my higher payoff, I would also benefit from R when they pick B.

Since the game is repeated, there's a chance that my opponent might switch strategies as we go along. If they don't, picking B consistently would result in an average payoff of 12$ per round, which isn't very attractive given that I can potentially get 42$ or 45$ by occasionally switching to R when the opponent picks B.

Given my preference for avoiding unnecessary risks and wanting a stable average payoff over the long run, I would choose to pick R as my strategy, appended with {R} at the end of my username in this forum. However, it's essential to remember that the opponent's actual behavior may deviate from rational expectations, which could influence the outcome of the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

As I chose R in the previous round and my opponent also picked R, we both receive a payoff of 45$ each. In this new round, I will again choose R since my strategy is to occasionally switch to R when my opponent picks B. If my opponent sticks with their strategy of always picking R, I should continue to pick R as well to maximize my average payoff over the long run. So, I chose R for this round, appended with {R} at the end of my username in this forum.

If my opponent continues to pick R, I would have maximized my payoff by occasionally switching strategies between R and B. So, I chose B for this round, appended with {B} at the end of my username in this forum.
